Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Identifying Technical and Non-Technical Feature Requirements to Generate Income-Earning Opportunities for Inexperienced Entrepreneurs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to discover some of the technical and non-technical "hidden" requirements for technology-driven, shared-economy entrepreneurship. This research will uncover the degree to which these hidden requirements are a challenge, especially for those who are not habitual shared-economy participants. Sharing economy platforms such as Uber, Lyft, eBay, Etsy, and Airbnb connect buyers and sellers and allow novice entrepreneurs to do business online. The sharing economy narrative emphasizes job creation and an easy ramp to small-scale entrepreneurship. Critics, however, have called into question what these systems actually provide for the least well-off, many of whom have limited experience with entrepreneurship and digital technology. This project very intentionally seeks broader impacts that aim to make the sharing economy more inclusive by simultaneously harnessing the strengths of local citizens, increasing community engagement, and raising economic prospects for the less well-off. A direct outcome of the research is to kick-start a working model for turning everyday citizens into tech-enabled, small-scale entrepreneurs.

The research will follow a case study approach consisting of observations, participatory design exercises, informant interviews, and focus groups to examine the foundational factors that enable participants to successfully operate in a shared economy around tourism. Actively participating with the community, the team of researchers will use a participatory approach to embed this investigation into the working of an enterprise in which community members conduct neighborhood tours as a way to earn additional income. Participants will design the tours, handle logistics, and ultimately deliver the tours. For the purposes of analysis, documentation, and recording of all technical and non-technical support required to run the business, the research will elicit participant aspirations, run design exercises to determine tour content, and provide technical assistance and connections with legal and business advisors. The factors enabling successful participation in the sharing economy are poorly understood, especially with regard to non-technical components. The intellectual goal of this investigation will be to uncover the hidden needs and limitations of traditional sharing economy platforms and to identify methods required to meet these needs and requirements, especially as they relate to inexperienced entrepreneurs.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

POR.DRECONTENT:
Uber, Lyft, eBay, Etsy, and Airbnb and other sharing economy platforms connect buyers and sellers and allow novice entrepreneurs to manage businesses online. These platforms provide a route to small-scale entrepreneurship; however, it is unclear whether such systems enable an easy ramp for the least well-off, many of whom have limited experience with entrepreneurship and digital technology.  To investigate this question, we took a three-part approach to our study. First, we took a community-based participatory research approach to assess the concept of neighborhood tour businesses as an opportunity to provide locals with an alternative financial safety net without requiring extensive educational preparation or funding. Our goal was to understand whether and why existing digital tools to support entrepreneurial endeavors disproportionately favor those with pre­existing entrepreneurial advantages. We found that in addition to technical requirements, a range of non-technological efforts is needed to manage projects, build trust and self-efficacy, and otherwise support community participants, which presents an alternative to claims about the future of technologies being able to address certain classes of social challenges. In our second approach, we interviewed 26 micro-entrepreneurs in Detroit to understand what drove them to perform entrepreneurship and how technologies supported or inhibited their efforts when performing entrepreneurship in resource-constrained environments. We found that unexpected life disruptions, barriers to maintaining traditional employment, and a desire to support local community needs often pushed them into entrepreneurship. This form of necessity-driven entrepreneurship formed how they used technology to achieve agency with respect to privacy, safety, and day-to-day work practices in ways that differed from entrepreneurship that was not necessity-driven. In our final approach, we compared our findings with a separate study of resource-constrained entrepreneurs from Ghana. This comparison revealed that entrepreneurs in both regions shared three common attributes. (1) They both exhibited efforts to "upgrade the self": while maintaining a precarious livelihood, entrepreneurs had a future-­oriented outlook towards learning how to perform entrepreneurship and used technologies for creating new career opportunities. (2) They both required "technology maintenance" as they used older generations of technologies for the purpose of entrepreneurship. As a result, repair or learning how to use newer technologies on older devices was critical. (3). Finally, they both consistently applied labor towards “overcoming exclusion". ­­

Project outcomes from our first study include increased confidence in tour leaders' ability to build and manage a business; connections with others working on early-stage businesses; and training on how to use computer technologies and social media needed to gain traction in today's tech-driven economy. Additional project outcomes include a tangible approach called socio­technical capacity building (STCB), which we define as "the strengthening of ability and motivation for people in resource-­constrained communities to achieve their goals through socio­technical skills while building on the existing assets of their local community." This enabled tour leaders to set up and manage websites and technology needed for communication and advertising. Findings from our final two studies contribute implications for how social technologies can be designed to better meet the employment needs of those who live in resource-constrained communities inside and outside of the United States.


 

 


Last Modified: 06/17/2019
Modified by: Tawanna Dillahunt
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Uber, Lyft, eBay, Etsy, and Airbnb and other sharing economy platforms connect buyers and sellers and allow novice entrepreneurs to manage businesses online. These platforms provide a route to small-scale entrepreneurship; however, it is unclear whether such systems enable an easy ramp for the least well-off, many of whom have limited experience with entrepreneurship and digital technology. To investigate this question, we took a three-part approach to our study. First, we took a community-based participatory research approach to assess the concept of neighborhood tour businesses as an opportunity to provide locals with an alternative financial safety net without requiring extensive educational preparation or funding. Our goal was to understand whether and why existing digital tools to support entrepreneurial endeavors disproportionately favor those with pre­existing entrepreneurial advantages. We found that in addition to technical requirements, a range of non-technological efforts is needed to manage projects, build trust and self-efficacy, and otherwise support community participants, which presents an alternative to claims about the future of technologies being able to address certain classes of social challenges. In our second approach, we interviewed 26 micro-entrepreneurs in Detroit to understand what drove them to perform entrepreneurship and how technologies supported or inhibited their efforts when performing entrepreneurship in resource-constrained environments. We found that unexpected life disruptions, barriers to maintaining traditional employment, and a desire to support local community needs often pushed them into entrepreneurship. This form of necessity-driven entrepreneurship formed how they used technology to achieve agency with respect to privacy, safety, and day-to-day work practices in ways that differed from entrepreneurship that was not necessity-driven. In our final approach, we compared our findings with a separate study of resource-constrained entrepreneurs from Ghana. This comparison revealed that entrepreneurs in both regions shared three common attributes. (1) They both exhibited efforts to "upgrade the self": while maintaining a precarious livelihood, entrepreneurs had a future-­oriented outlook towards learning how to perform entrepreneurship and used technologies for creating new career opportunities. (2) They both required "technology maintenance" as they used older generations of technologies for the purpose of entrepreneurship. As a result, repair or learning how to use newer technologies on older devices was critical. (3). Finally, they both consistently applied labor towards "overcoming exclusion". ­­ Project outcomes from our first study include increased confidence in tour leaders' ability to build and manage a business; connections with others working on early-stage businesses; and training on how to use computer technologies and social media needed to gain traction in today's tech-driven economy. Additional project outcomes include a tangible approach called socio­technical capacity building (STCB), which we define as "the strengthening of ability and motivation for people in resource-­constrained communities to achieve their goals through socio­technical skills while building on the existing assets of their local community." This enabled tour leaders to set up and manage websites and technology needed for communication and advertising. Findings from our final two studies contribute implications for how social technologies can be designed to better meet the employment needs of those who live in resource-constrained communities inside and outside of the United States.
